a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: Lines and phrases on both sides of this manuscript leaf contributed to portions of the poem that would eventually be titled "Song of Myself," indicating a composition date before 1855. However, the manuscript also includes lines that contributed to "Sun-Down Poem" (later retitled "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry") in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass. Edward Grier notes that while this may indicate that the manuscript was composed at various times before and after 1855, the "date of the earliest drafts of 'Crossing Brooklyn Ferry' may well have been before 1855" (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 1:165).

bibl.author: Walt Whitman

bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

revisionDesc.change: converted from P4 to P5, checked

div1.p: Rule in all addresses—and poems and other writings, etc.—Do not undertake to say anything however plain to you, unless you are positive it will be are making it perfectly plain to those who hear or read.—Make it plain.—
Unhappy character.—One who depends mostly upon others for his or her happiness, will never have any at all.—To be constantly watching the changes in people you love is
One must be contained within himself—otherwise the world is all in vain.—

work.p: Several of these phrases and lines are probably related to portions of the poem that would eventually be titled "Song of Myself," particularly the phrase "mate and companion" and the line that begins "I say that every man is great..."

lg.l: I say to my own greatness, Away!

I will not be a leader of men, I will always be their
mate and companion!
I do not desire eminence, I desire equality.

I will break up this demention that man is the
servant of God, or of many gods;

I say that nothing is every man he is great to himself and
every woman to herself;

And that to take an inferior place or be humble
is unbecoming

work.p: Several of these phrases and lines are related to portions of the poem that would eventually be titled "Song of Myself." The manuscript line that reads "A mother as well as father, a child as well as a man" becomes, in the first poem of the 1855 Leaves, the line "Maternal as well as paternal, a child as well as a man." And several manuscript lines, beginning with "Not only an American..." become, in the poem, the lines beginning "Not merely of the New World..." Edward Grier speculates that Whitman's note to "Don't forget the bombardment" is in reference to the "bombardment" of the "old artillerist" in "Song of Myself."

lg.l: A father A mother as well as father, a child as well as a man;
ANot only an American, but an African Europeand, and Asiatic,
A lawyer, a doctor, a priest, a farmer sailor, an artist,

transpose.l: A farmer, a carpenter, a blacksmith, a sailor, a cook,

Capable of all that is ugly and mean, and capable of all that
is pure and heroic,

lg.l: Ignorant and accomplished, a chaos and a perfect system an answering purpose;
Elasticity is I am—and I am the solid palpable dense rock—and I the I this invisible as the gas of the air—
Scheming, storming planning, loving cautioning
Appearing and d Laughing and weeping, Backing and filling, appearing and disappearing
I travel day and night such these eternal roads

work.p: The phrase "the fool and the wise thinker" is probably related to a similar phrase ("The stupid and the wise thinker") in the poem that would eventually be titled "Song of Myself." The phrase "outward and outward" may be related to the line from "Song of Myself" that reads "All goes onward and outward....and nothing collapses."

lg.l: In me are the old and young the foolish and the wise observer thinker
I enclose the heroic, and I enclose the mean and vicious.—
Life in the universe—a vast circular procession whose ? rings expand outward and outward

work.p: Several phrases of this prose were later used, in somewhat revised form, in a line for "Sun-down Poem" in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass. The poem would later be titled "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry." A portion of the manuscript reads: "I doubt whether my greatest thoughts, as I had supposed them, are not shallow.—and people will most likely laugh at me." The line in the poem reads: "My great thoughts, as I supposed them, were they not in reality meagre? Would not people laugh at me?"

div1.p: Every thing I have done seems to me blank and shallow and suspicious.—I doubt whether who my greatest thoughts, as I had supposed them, are not shallow.—and people will most likely laugh at them.— me.—My pride is impotent; my love gets no response.—The complacency of nature is hateful—for I am so filled with restlessness.—I am so incomplete.—

We do not so much care what people say—we are deeply interested in what they do.—If we can imagine nothing left of a man but talk,—would not that be a ridiculous remnant?—Yet a deaf and dumb person might still be one of the heroes.—

work.p: It is possible that some of these poetic lines contributed to the preface to the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. The idea of common people being greater than Presidents or Major Generals (from the manuscript) may be related to the sentence from the Preface that reads: "Other states indicate themselves in their deputies....but the genius of the United States is not best or most in its executives or legislatures, nor in its ambassadors or authors or colleges or churches or parlors, nor even in its newspapers or inventors...but always most in the common people." The manuscript line "I remain with them all on equal terms" may also be related to the Preface ("The messages of great poets to each man and woman are, Come to us on equal terms").

lg.l:
It is only the shallow who Do you suppose I would lift themselves myself out of
their race by something eminent and specially attractive.—
I am not quite such a fool as that
I am too great to be a mere President or Major General

I amremain with my fellows,—with mechanics, and farmers
and common people;
I remain with them all on equal terms

work.p: It is possible that Whitman's note about a "Poem descriptive of a good wife" is in reference to "Poem of Women" from the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass (the poem was later titled "Unfolded Out of the Folds").

div1.p: There are many great painters—they paint scenes from the books, and illustrate from what the romancer and rhymster has prepared before them.—This artist does not illustrate or paint any such scenes or groups or characters.—He delineates for from himself.—Do you not like this magnificent disdain? of—
div1.ab:
Poem descriptive of a good wife
(housekeeper, cook, mother of many children.)

Poem
What is beauty?
Beauty is simply health.
